Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Small RNA regulation and the evolution of extreme anoxia tolerance
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will trace the evolution of low-oxygen tolerance in vertebrates. The study may reveal novel cellular mechanisms underpinning anoxia tolerance, which may transform our prevention and treatment of heart attack and stroke. Humans, and most other vertebrates, can survive for only a few minutes without adequate blood flow to the heart and brain. Loss of blood flow blocks the supply of oxygen, and quickly leads to tissue anoxia, or lack of oxygen. Yet, there are a handful of vertebrates that can survive for months in the complete absence of oxygen. This project examines and compares the expression of genes involved in anoxia tolerance of species from each major vertebrate group. The project will also promote international scientific collaboration and provide training of a female Ph.D. candidate and undergraduate student. Additionally, research findings will be presented to a Science Research Methods class at St. Mary?s Academy, a local all-girls high school.

To study small RNA expression and the evolution of anoxia tolerance, small RNA expression will be examined in the epaulette shark, crucian carp, annual killifish embryos, leopard frog, and freshwater turtles. These species represent the most anoxia-tolerant cartilaginous fish, bony fishes, amphibians and reptiles, respectively. This research tests the hypothesis that common small RNAs support the anoxia tolerance of these few most tolerant vertebrates, indicating a convergent evolution of the life history trait. Known hypoxia-responsive and novel anoxia-responsive small RNAs were recently identified in the anoxia tolerant annual killifish Austrofundulus limnaeus. This project will test the role of small RNAs in the evolution and maintenance of anoxia tolerance by comparing them among anoxia-tolerant vertebrate species. Each species will be exposed to anoxia and recovery at its ecologically relevant temperature and sampled at 3 time points: A.) prior to anoxia; B.) during anoxia; C.) during aerobic recovery following anoxia. The specific exposure intervals are set based on the maximal anoxia tolerance of each species. Total RNA will be extracted from brain tissue, since the brain is the most anoxia-sensitive organ, and prepared for small RNA sequencing, and expression patterns will be compared.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merits:

Few vertebrates can survive for days to months without oxygen. This project took a comparative approach to understanding the evolution of anoxia tolerance in vertebrates and the role of a regulatory genetic element, small RNA. The small RNA expression patterns over anoxia and recovery were compared for the most anoxia-tolerant vertebrates: the epaulette shark, annual killifish, crucian carp, painted turtle, and leopard frog, representing major vertebrate lineages. We found that each anoxia-tolerant vertebrate studied had a different small RNA response pattern, indicating that different mechanisms have evolved to support anoxia tolerance at the cellular and genetic level. This suggests that there likely are many different ways for small RNAs to help coordinate and regulate survival without oxygen, making further studies on small RNAs and anoxia very interesting. Since many different expression strategies exist in the face of anoxia, perhaps there is a combination of sequences in humans that can impact the ability to survive a heart attack or stroke, both medical conditions related to oxygen depravation. This project opens up new lines of research to pursue in biomedicine. Additionally, we found that the small RNAs derived from the mitochondrial genome found in the annual killifish don’t present as important players in the other anoxia-tolerant species. This suggests that these sequences and their role in anoxia tolerance may be unique to the annual killifish A. limnaeus and thus merits further study to understand its biology. This project has generated new additions to the databases of small RNAs, and as such provides a jumping off point for further comparative research on small RNAs and anoxia tolerance.

 

Broader Impacts:

In addition to the intellectual merits gained by this project, the broader impact is also notable. The PhD student was responsible for the success of the project from the start to finish. She developed the idea for the project, wrote the grant, and contacted potential collaborators. The PhD student and a female undergraduate student conducted the laboratory research. This gave the PhD student daily experience, throughout the summer, in mentoring a young researcher and overseeing the project. The PhD student was also responsible for communicating and coordinating with 4 other collaborators, from other universities across the national and in Europe. As a result, she gained incredible experience mentoring, managing, collaborating, and overseeing the success of her project from start to finish. This helped her develop important skills and confidence necessary to be an independent scientist. Establishing new collaborative relationships with other labs, including one international lab, also have the potential to lead to new projects. The undergraduate student who worked on the project gained practice in precise molecular biology techniques and experimental design. She gained confidence, enthusiasm, and competence as a researcher, which lead her to pursue and successfully obtain new research positions. This project has substantially contributed to the development of these two female researchers, and their retention in the sciences. The project was also presented to fellow graduate students, professors, and alumni of the biology department at Portland State University as part of the annual alumni night, generating knowledge of and interest in this comparative project. The project and results will also be presented at St. Mary’s Academy, an all-girls high school in downtown Portland. This will further impact more woman in science, and hopefully aid in the attracting more young women to STEM.
